title: Devastating story behind Netflix documentary Tell Me Who I Am
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

**Trigger warning: this piece discusses childhood abuse**

There is a ‘deeply upsetting’ and heartbreaking story behind Netflix’s latest documentary, Tell Me Who I Am, that’s rattling the heartstrings.

Based on the true story of twins Alex and Marcus Lewis, it follows on from their 2013 memoir of the same name, beginning with the story of Alex, who, after a near-fatal motorbike accident in 1982 at the age of 18 loses all memory.

He has forgotten everything of the preceding nearly two-decades. He has no idea where his home is or who his parents are. He can’t even remember his own name or the name of simple household objects. The only thing he does know is that the person sitting next to him is his identical twin brother, Marcus.

Advertisement

Soon after, Alex relies on Marcus to give him his memory back; to tell him who he is, so to speak.

Marcus acts as his twin’s surrogate memory imparting all the information the teenager needs to know: from telling him about his girlfriend and his friends, to the incredibly strict rules of their house, run by their malevolent stepfather and mother.

What begins as a story about one twin teaching the other about life soon becomes a heartbreaking tale of the secret Marcus had chosen to keep from Alex in order to build the idyllic childhood he felt his brother deserved.

Marcus and Alex Lewis (Picture: Netflix)

It’s here the viewer discovers their childhood was marred by abuse.

‘We’re identical twins; we’re bonded, and this thing was so strong that it almost broke us apart,” Marcus said in the unbelievably emotional film.

His brother Alex added: ‘The secrets I need answers to are in Marcus’s head. But they’re deep in his head, so it would almost seem reckless in terms of what we are going to find.’

The brothers confronted their past together (Picture: Netflix)

It soon becomes known the secrets Marcus was attempting to bury, that is, the pair were sexually abused by their mother until the age of 14.

If it wasn’t for a curious Alex who, after being tasked alongside his brother with unlocking rooms in their house to which they had previously been forbidden, following the death of their mother, Marcus may have been able to protect his sibling forever.

Marcus was attempting to protect his brother (Picture: Netflix)

Alex was seeking answers (Picture: Netflix)

However after finding a nude image of himself, Alex demanded answers and, at the age of 32, had to rebuild his life once more. Searching for answers, his brother held the key to his identity for a second time.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Marcus, who remembered everything, attempted to ignore his abuse and spoke not a word of the extent of it to anyone – until sitting down for this documentary. Even the men’s memoir didn’t dive into what they experienced as boys. Marcus’s admission culminates in a teary heart-to-heart between the brothers in front of cameras.

Tell Me Who I Am asks the viewer a moral dilemma – do you lie in order to protect, or tell the truth and risk horrendous consequences.

It’s been dubbed an ‘important watch’ by one viewer, who wrote: ‘I was not mentally or emotionally prepared for Tell Me Who I Am on @netflix… the last 15 mins are a tough but important watch.’

Finding the emotional anguish in the brothers’ tortured childhood, another added on Twitter: ‘This documentary is a kick in the teeth and a dagger in the heart. I’ve seen some documentaries in my time but nothing prepared me for this.’

Dissecting the horrendous position Marcus was put in as he debated over telling his brother the truth, one added: ‘Watched a truly staggering #Documentary on #Netflix last night. Utterly unfathomable the dilemma this guy was put in and utterly heartbreaking #tellmewhoiam.’

‘Devastated. Such a quietly disturbing, but riveting doc,’ one viewer felt, after it was released on the weekend. ‘It’s so deeply upsetting on so many levels.’

After the film premiered earlier this year at the Telluride Film Festival, director Ed Perkins told Salon: ‘It’s one of those stories, that if it wasn’t true, you wouldn’t believe it. I thought the themes of memory and identity, truth and lies, and the blurring of fact and fiction were fascinating.’

Advertisement

Since the telling of their story, the twins have been contacted by those sharing similar stories of childhood abuse.

‘We’ve had hundreds of letters,’ Marcus said, as Alex added: ‘We’ve had meetings with people with similar stories to ours, middle-aged people.’

Marcus added: ‘Every time that somebody tells you a story, you feel that you’re helping them because they’re speaking about it.

‘So that kind of makes you feel useful.’
